<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_NewNode:
```c
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
```
</target_code>

<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Yes. The call memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize) can access beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by its pointer parameters in realistic error situations. Example violation scenarios: (1) malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize) can overflow size_t (or otherwise fail to allocate the requested size) so the allocated region after the union is smaller than DataSize; memcpy then writes past the allocated destination. (2) malloc can return NULL (no check is performed); subsequent use of AllocNode (and &AllocNode[1]) is invalid and memcpy will access out-of-bounds memory. (3) The source pointer Data may be NULL or point to an object smaller than DataSize (caller error), causing memcpy to read beyond the source object. Any of these lead to a Rule 21.17 violation.
